abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is highly unsatisfactory, sustainability is
            highly unlikely, institutional development impact is
            negligible, Bank performance is unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance is highly unsatisfactory. Lessons learned were
            grouped around the following issues: 1) The Bank needs to
            have a clearer idea of when engagement is simply not
            effective. In this case, the Bank accepted poor
            implementation and weak policies and commitment in order to
            stay engaged. 2) The Bank should be diligent about moving
            quickly on corruption issues. The Bank could have moved
            sooner in Turkmenistan, given the gravity of the violation
            and the fact that there was little evidence of true changes
            in behavior. 3) One size-fits-all post-Soviet TA projects
            are not appropriate in all settings. Governance and
            implementation capacity, particularly decision-making, in
            Turkmenistan were far too weak to expect success in a
            standard TA project. 4)  If the Bank is going to reactivate
            a project with a new focus, it needs to allow a reasonable
            amount of time for implementation. The decision to put the
            reactivated project on a "short leash" was
            appropriate given the difficulties of the past; however, one
            year for a treasury component is highly unrealistic.
